ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the magical practices in Egypt and the greater Near East.
good overview of Near Eastern cultures. Very interesting.
A broad outline as well as specific examples of the ways magic and ritual work in ancient Egypt, Mesopotamia and the early Islamic world.

I learned about the challenge of distinguishing between magic and ritual in ancient cultures, and about how ideas about magic and ritual developed over time in Egypt, Mesopotamia, and up through the modern Middle East.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some of the lectures could be hard to follow because they had so much content, but the guest speakers and visits to the Babylonian collection were really fun.
Lecture style is not great, but the content was interesting.

I would have found it more helpful if more time in class was dedicated to talking about the assigned readings or connecting them to the lecture in class, and if the assignments could have been taken more care about in terms of incorporating them into the schedule/context of the course.
Great balance of breadth and depth in terms of the ancient societies and topics covered.
Strengths included a variety of topics spanning magic and ritual across the Near East, flexible deadlines, and a great depth of knowledge from the professor and all of the guest lecturers

The subject matter is very interesting and the comparison across cultures is a strength. A weakness is that there is a lot of busy work for the course with several short summary papers. It would have also been nice to spend a little more time on the Islamic magic section.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, lots of good learning and it was fun at times too.
Yes I would for those really interested in Near Eastern cultures like Ancient Egypt. It being a lecture made it hard to really stay engaged with, but the content was definitely interesting.
Would recommend to people who have a bit of background in the relevant regions/cultures or in the study of magic in anthropology.
Yes, it was a very interesting course and useful to anyone who wants to learn more about the mindsets and religious practices of ancient cultures.
